doc_subject: WITHDRAWAL OF NEW ZEALAND FORCES FROM SINGAPORE

claims.claim_text: DCM reviewed the matter of the withdrawal of NZ forces from Singapore with Acting New Zealand High Commissioner Dawson during a luncheon conversation on April 29.
entities: Acting New Zealand High Commissioner Dawson

claims.claim_text: There were somewhat differing versions in reftels concerning the degree of GOS initiative in requesting the withdrawal of NZ forces from Singapore.
Dawson said Deputy P.M. Talboys had been the first to raise the question of continued stationing of NZ forces in Singapore.
Deputy P.M. Goh replied by saying that GOS could no longer expect New Zealand forces to fight Singapore's battles.
Deputy P.M. Goh expressed appreciation for the contribution of New Zealand forces to the stability of the region.
Deputy P.M. Goh indicated there was no longer a need for the presence of New Zealand forces in Singapore.
P.M. Lee was 'somewhat more oblique' in his remarks regarding the withdrawal of NZ forces.
P.M. Lee's remarks generally confirmed the position taken by Mr. Goh regarding the withdrawal of NZ forces.
Both P.M. Lee and Deputy P.M. Goh were quite willing to accommodate GNZ desires concerning the timing of the withdrawal of these forces.
Air Commodore Gunton (Commander New Zealand Forces Singapore) confirmed the position regarding the withdrawal of NZ forces to DAO in a separate conversation.
Dawson said Lee indicated that the best way to counter the communist threat to SEA was through economic development of the ASEAN countries.
The implication was that stationing foreign forces in the area was an outmoded way of dealing with communist subversion and insurgency.
The implication was that stationing foreign forces in the area was not an especially relevant way of dealing with communist subversion and insurgency.

claims.claim_text: A more intensive effort will be needed to induce the FRG to be more forthcoming about AWACS at the December DPC Ministerial.
The cable's author cannot endorse Embassy London's recommendation that it be authorized to inform the UK of the proposed demarche.
British-German friction on Alliance military matters is currently on the rise.
It makes little sense for the US to get in the middle of British-German friction.
Minister Leber told the cable's author on November 3 that he was convinced of the importance of the AEW system and positively disposed towards the concept.
The FRG lacked confidence that AWACS would function as intended.
The FRG remains unconvinced that AWACS is sufficiently well developed or cost-studied to warrant a NATO commitment to purchase it at this time.
A personal approach to Leber from Secretary Rumsfeld would appear to be the best hope of changing this FRG position.
The scheduling of payments is a major concern for the Germans regarding AEW.
It would ease matters considerably for the FRG if its participation in an AEW program involved smaller payments in the initial years balanced by larger payments in later years.
The FRG has emphasized that a NATO AEW program must be a truly NATO effort, not one of a few NATO allies.
The technical complexities of incorporating a NATO AEW into the current ground system is a major German concern.
The German military services are uniformly opposed to AWACS because they regard it as a threat to programs they have already endorsed and budgeted.
The civilian leadership has been unable to overcome the reluctance of the German military services.
The cable's author is inclined to view the German reservation regarding the ground support system as a serious one.
From discussions with non-German sources, the cable's author has the impression that perhaps the FRG has raised the issue of the ground support system to use AWACS for improving the NADGE system.
The tension building between the Germans and the British worries the cable's author most.
Brandt on the German side suggested that the British would turn down the tank gun offer simply for reasons of prestige.
The cable's author believes American interests will not be served by the US stepping into the middle of the British-German dispute.
The cable's author does not concur with London's recommendation to inform the British of any further demarche the US might make to the Germans, except perhaps in a very general way.

doc_subject: HOUSE APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEE STAFFDEL VISIT TO EUROPE RE PROPOSED          EUCOM RELOCATION

claims.claim_text: STAFFDEL returned to the mission on the afternoon of March 11 for a brief follow-on discussion with the Deputy Defense Advisor.
The discussion was on the subject of EUCOM collocation.
No new ground was plowed during the discussion.
STAFFDEL's questions centered on the potential reaction of allies other than Belgium and FRG to a move.
Talley and Gies said they expect their final report will go to the Subcommittee on Military Construction in two weeks.
According to Talley, the Subcommittee on Military Construction is not yet aware of the political implications related to the collocation question.
Gies said he believes the Subcommittee members will be disturbed if money is asked for before negotiations have opened with Belgium and the FRG.
Talley and Gies say they intend to describe the potential political issues in their report.

claims.claim_text: QUAI DEPUTY DIRECTOR IN CHARGE OF NORTH AFRICAN AFFAIRS (ALBIS) informed 'us' on September 6.
The French Ambassador in Tripoli carried out a demarche to the GOL on Monday, September 4.
The French demarche to the GOL followed 'our' approach.
'Our' original demarche on this subject occurred.
The French Ambassador had raised the question with Quai Secretary General Soutou.
The meeting between the French Ambassador and Quai Secretary General Soutou occurred on August 25.
ALBIS was skimpy with details of the French demarche.
The French demarche had been in the form of a protest.
The French demarche was related to French desire for improved Libyan-French relations.
France desires improved Libyan-French relations.
ALBIS said there was no Libyan reaction to the demarche.
There was no Libyan reaction to the demarche.

claims.claim_text: The USG followed up an earlier demarche (Ref B) with MFA Director for Middle Eastern Affairs Santarelli on August 7, 1978.
entities: MFA Director for Middle Eastern Affairs Santarelli

claims.claim_text: Santarelli said that the French informed the Italians about the origin of weapons used in a terrorist incident at Orly.
Santarelli said that the MFA instructed the Italian Ambassador in Tripoli to raise the issue with the Libyans.
The GOL has not yet responded to the demarche.
The Italians are satisfied that the GOL knows that the GOI knows of Libyan supply of Italian arms to terrorists.
Santarelli cautioned that the foregoing information is considered very sensitive in the GOI.
Santarelli cautioned that the foregoing information is for USG information only.
Santarelli cautioned that the foregoing information should not be discussed with Italian diplomats elsewhere or with other governments.
Santarelli said the MFA is not clear about exactly what is intended regarding a joint demarche.
The Italians are not necessarily opposed to the idea of a further demarche.
The Italians feel that they have already registered their reaction in a bilateral approach.
For political and economic reasons, the USG does not believe the Italians would be willing to join in a "tough demarche" to the Libyans on this issue.
From the Italian point of view, they have already taken a courageous step in confronting the GOL with their knowledge of weapons supply.
The Italians are not likely to want to pursue the issue with the GOL any further.

claims.claim_text: Quai Director for Africa (Georgy) believes the Soviets maintain their ambitions for expansion in Africa.
Georgy thinks the Soviets are currently taking one step back in Africa to avoid confrontation with the West.
The Soviets stressed the need to "de-dramatize" the African situation.
Georgy reports that the Soviets appeared to value the opportunity to discuss Africa with the French.
The Soviets told Georgy they cannot discuss Africa with other powers.
The Soviets stated that discussions with the US always come back to strategic issues such as SALT.
Georgy thought the Soviets had little real understanding of the complexities and fragility of African affairs.
Georgy surmised that the Soviets were in the process of taking one step back after trying to take two big steps forward and meeting Western resistance.
Georgy said the Soviets appeared to see the Western role in Africa in terms of encirclement of the Soviet Union.
Georgy said the Soviets claimed the US airlift of troops to Shaba was part of a broad NATO strategy.
Georgy believes the Soviets have an important interest in stability in North Africa.
Georgy said the expansion of Soviet ties with Morocco has placed the Soviets in a position where they wish to avoid choosing sides between the Algerians and the Moroccans.
Georgy believes the Soviets would probably "do what was necessary" to make possible a settlement in the Sahara.
Georgy said the Soviets were deeply troubled by Qadhafi because of his adventurism and religious fanaticism.
Georgy noted that the Soviets were particularly angered that Jalloud chose to visit Peking when the Sino-Japanese Peace and Friendship Treaty was signed.
Georgy thought the consultations had been worthwhile.
The cable's author would not be surprised if the consultations were to become a regular feature of Franco-Soviet relations.
Quai Director for Africa (Georgy) returned from two days of intensive consultations in Moscow on Africa, August 9-10.

claims.claim_text: 1976 is an election year in Malta.

Both Mintoff's Laborites and the opposition Nationalists believe that Malta's strategic Mediterranean location will still be sufficiently valuable to NATO to justify continuation after 1979 of some form of annual monetary subsidy.
The USG has serious doubts that Malta's strategic Mediterranean location will still be sufficiently valuable to NATO to justify continuation after 1979 of some form of annual monetary subsidy.

It will be essential for the USG and NATO to reach conclusions concerning Malta's future as soon as possible after the 1976 elections to avoid another crisis management exercise resulting from Maltese blackmailing tactics.
Bilateral U.S. interests in Malta have been, and will remain, limited.
If NATO's Southern Tier remains intact, Malta in the 1980's might not matter that much to the other Alliance members either.
The 325,000 Maltese appear to be fairly evenly divided between support for Mintoff's Socialist Labor Party and the conservative Nationalist Party.
The Maltese Parliament's mandate expires in August 1976, and a general election is required by November 1976.
The Embassy leans to the view that Mintoff and the Labor Party probably will be reelected in a very close contest.
If the Nationalists return to power, there will be an opportunity for closer ties between Malta and the U.S. and possibly for resumption of Sixth Fleet visits, but only at a stiff price.
The major U.S. interest in Malta is not a bilateral one, but part of the multilateral concern of the NATO Alliance regarding Mediterranean security.

The major U.S. policy objectives in Malta include denial of Soviet access to Malta, retention of Malta's military facilities for the West (including Sixth Fleet access), and continuation of Malta's ties to the West.
Mintoff's foreign policy continues to be the avoidance of involvement with either of the superpowers; hence, neither Soviet nor U.S. fleets are welcome in Malta.
The revised British/Maltese Military Facilities Agreement (MFA), signed in March 1972, runs until March 31, 1979.
The MFA specifically provides that the Government of Malta shall not permit the forces of any Warsaw Pact member to be stationed in Malta or to use Maltese military facilities.
There continues to be a complete denial of access to Malta by any U.S. military or naval forces, including the Sixth Fleet, as long as Mintoff is Prime Minister.
Neither the Labor Party nor the Nationalist Party really has firm plans for what happens to Malta after 1977 or after the March 1979 expiration of the MFA.
Malta's economic viability is clearly dependent on either some form of continued monetary subsidy or a significant new development like the discovery of offshore oil.
The British have stated that their decision to leave Malta by 1979 is firm and irrevocable.
The Embassy recommends the USG and other NATO governments should avoid any attempts to buy Mintoff's favor before the election, as such initiatives would be wasted and seen as taking sides.

doc_subject: FCO WISHES TO HOLD UP DISCUSSION OF BRITISH STUDY ON ISRAELI SECURITY  REQUIREMENTS

claims.claim_text: The FCO wishes to hold up discussion of the British Study on Israeli Security Requirements.
entities: British Study on Israeli Security Requirements

claims.claim_text: The FCO formally passed copies of the British Study on Israeli Security Requirements to the Embassy on the morning of April 21, 1977.
entities: British Study on Israeli Security Requirements

claims.claim_text: The Embassy pouched two copies of the British Study on Israeli Security Requirements to the Department for Day and Kontos on April 21, 1977.
entities: British Study on Israeli Security Requirements

claims.claim_text: FCO Assistant Under Secretary Weir and Blatherwick separately called EMBOFF on the evening of April 21, 1977, to inform them of developments.
Foreign Secretary Owen had ordered the British Study on Israeli Security Requirements.
entities: British Study on Israeli Security Requirements

claims.claim_text: Foreign Secretary Owen suddenly showed interest in the study on the afternoon of April 21, 1977.
Foreign Secretary Owen asked that the study be shown to him for approval before it was passed to the USG.
Foreign Secretary Owen's subordinates are embarrassed by the fact they have already released the study to the USG.
Foreign Secretary Owen's subordinates asked the Embassy if they could hold the study and treat it temporarily as a "non-document".
EMBOFF explained that they had already put copies of the study in the pouch and informed the Department they had received it.
The FCO requested that the Department treat the British Study as a "preliminary FCO working paper" until Owen agrees to release it to the USG.
FCO officers hoped Department officers would avoid mentioning receipt of the study to the British pending approval and release by Owen.
Weir is seeking approval and release of the study by Owen.

doc_subject: SUBJECT HOUSE APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEE STAFFDEL VISIT TO EUROPE RE          PROPOSED EUCOM RELOCATION

claims.claim_text: The Ambassador met with the Staffdel on the morning of March 7.
The meeting was held to discuss political questions related to a possible EUCOM move to SHAPE.
The Ambassador stressed the need to carefully consider the potential problem of an apparent "Americanization" of SHAPE.
The Ambassador stressed possible Allied perceptions of an "Americanization" of the Alliance as a whole if a move were undertaken without full consultation and Alliance support.
The Ambassador stressed the need for careful consideration of the political implications for Belgium of a move, particularly while the Tindemans government has minority status.
The Ambassador stressed possible FRG concerns as outlined in Reference A.
The Ambassador highlighted the generally weak political positions of the Alliance governments for Messrs. Talley and Gies.
The Ambassador highlighted the Alliance governments' strong desire to be fully consulted regarding changes in plans and policies which Washington may be contemplating.
The Ambassador urged that full and careful consideration be given to the political implications of a move at this time, as opposed to a time when Alliance governments are stronger.

The Ambassador, drawing on his perspective as a former Ambassador to Belgium, outlined questions he believed the Government of Belgium would feel compelled to consider when reviewing any possible collocation proposals.
The Ambassador noted the principal reasons why the Government of Belgium may be reluctant to grasp the collocation nettle at this point.
Messrs. Talley and Gies were reminded that no decision has yet been made by the Administration on the EUCOM relocation issue.
Messrs. Talley and Gies were reminded that the EUCOM relocation issue is a potentially sensitive one which has not been explored with the Allies.
Talley and Gies indicated that they arrived in Europe with relatively little appreciation of the political factors related to a EUCOM move to Belgium.
The reporting embassy believes they were able to contribute to the process, which Embassy Bonn began, of enlarging Talley and Gies' understanding of the political factors and sensitivities involved.
The reporting embassy noted the reasoning which makes collocation operationally attractive.
Talley and Gies appeared concerned that the congressional funding process may outpace the process of political consultations with Belgium, the FRG, and other Allies.

The reporting embassy believes it should be made clear to all relevant members of Congress and staffs that no decisions on collocation have been made and that discussion of funding is thus premature, if the funding process outpacing consultations is a result of Executive Branch action.
The political sensitivity of the EUCOM relocation issue could usefully be underlined.
The Staffdel plans to return to USNATO for further discussions on March 11.

doc_subject: LEBANESE SITUATION REPORT AS OF 1730 FEBRUARY 10.

claims.claim_text: An uneasy cease-fire was in effect since around 2300 hours on February 9.
The uneasy cease-fire was broken at about 1300 hours on February 10.
Syrian artillery began shelling Ayn Ar-Rummanah at about 1300 hours on February 10.
The Syrians stopped shelling Ayn Ar-Rummanah about 1400 hours on February 10.
Sporadic small arms fire has occurred since about 1400 hours on February 10.
Local press reports that tension is rising as the deadline for the Commission of Inquiry's report nears the evening of February 10.
EMBOFFs reported virtually no traffic in the streets of Ashrafiyah around 1600 hours on February 10.
Lebanese Front leaders held an extraordinary meeting in Camille Chamoun's house in Ashrafiyah.
Lebanese Front leaders issued a conciliatory statement at 1415 hours on February 10.
The conciliatory statement expressed regret at incidents involving "friendly forces."
The conciliatory statement called for a joint investigative committee to decide who was responsible for the fighting.
The conciliatory statement appealed to all parties to exercise restraint.
The conciliatory statement expressed full confidence in President Sarkis.
A Lebanese Front military officer told ARMA that the Front expected the Syrians to mount an offensive against East Beirut the evening of February 10.
The Lebanese Front had prepared plans to counter the Syrians.
The Lebanese Front was confident it could repel the Syrians.
A Lebanese Front military officer said that an Israeli was in Lebanon.
A Lebanese Front military officer said that an Israeli had promised that the Israelis would give the Front any help it needed.

doc_subject: HONG KONG GOVERNMENT ATTITUDES TOWARD SINO-AMERICAN RELATIONS

claims.claim_text: An referenced INR report did not specifically mention Hong Kong.
The Hong Kong Government's (HKG) views on Sino-US relations and normalization were summarized recently by the HKG Political Advisor.
The HKG Political Advisor said that China's relations with the US and the West in general have improved.
The HKG Political Advisor said that Hong Kong's interaction with China has become easier and more productive as China's relations with the US and the West improved.
The POLAD believed normalization would neither directly benefit nor affect Hong Kong.
The POLAD believed normalization would affect Hong Kong if the PRC took action against Taiwan.
The POLAD believed a Chinese attack or even threat thereof against Taiwan would cause a massive capital hemorrhage from Hong Kong.
The POLAD believed a massive capital hemorrhage from Hong Kong could irreversibly destabilize the colony.
The POLAD did not expect a PRC move against Taiwan in the near term.
The POLAD thought Peking would concentrate on reincorporating Taiwan in other ways.
The POLAD thought Peking would turn to the question of Hong Kong and Macau after reincorporating Taiwan.

claims.claim_text: The reporting post shares the Department's interest in obtaining additional information regarding Libya's role in the Orly Airport terrorist incident.
The only information seen in traffic thus far is that arms used by terrorists were at an unknown time purchased from Italy by Libya.
The Libyans could easily side-step the issue of arms purchase by observing that their long-term support for Palestinian resistance movements, including provision of arms, is no secret.
The Libyans could easily side-step the issue of arms purchase by observing that how Palestinians use such arms is not Libyan responsibility.
It would be different if there was information that Libyans had armed terrorists specifically for Orly operations.
It would be different if there was information that arms had been transported to France by Libyans.
If evidence of direct Libyan involvement is obtained, Embassy Tripoli would recommend joining in a demarche to the Libyan government.
A problem has been the absence of convincing evidence linking the Libyan government with recent terrorist incidents.
The absence of convincing evidence prevents justification for a ban on export to Libya of Oshkosh trucks.
The absence of convincing evidence prevents justification for an announcement of restriction on Boeings to Libya.

US policy would be better understood by those within the Libyan government who say they are working for improved US-Libyan relations if hard information regarding Libyan involvement at Orly could be cited.
If Libyan participation in the Orly attack was limited to the original purchase of arms, a demarche would carry little weight.
Libyans would consider themselves victims of a hostile campaign if a demarche was based on a limited connection with the Orly attack.
Tunisians reportedly furnished passports in connection with the Orly attack.

doc_subject: (C) FORIGNERS RUMORED TO HAVE SOLD EVIDENCE LEADING TO WEI CONVICTION

claims.claim_text: Chinese sources told foreign experts that some Chinese officials believe 'foreigner Guo Li' (William Guo), a former VISNEWS employee, sold evidence against 'counterrevolutionary' Wei Jingsheng to Chinese officials for one million dollars.
According to the story, Guo sold a tape recording of Wei revealing 'military intelligence' to Reuter's correspondent Ian Mackenzie.
The tape recording was evidence that was used to convict Wei in his October 16 trial.
It is difficult to imagine such a transaction taking place.
The general belief among Wei's friends and other leading dissidents is that one or more foreigners provided evidence against Wei to Chinese Public Security officials.
The experts and their contacts believe the story is being officially encouraged.
The story is being officially encouraged as another example of foreign involvement in the dissident movement.
The story is being officially encouraged as an example of the unreliability of contacts with foreigners.
The story is being officially encouraged as an example of the danger of contacts with foreigners.

doc_subject: ROK REQUEST TO EXPORT M-67 HAND GRENADES TO MALAYSIA

claims.claim_text: A reftel requested comments from this Embassy regarding a possible sale of ROK-manufactured M-67 hand grenades to Malaysian Armed Forces.
The U.S. Government has approved a number of cash sales of U.S.-produced military equipment (helicopters, armored cars) to GOM.
The U.S. Government has a small ongoing FMS credit program (F5E's, probably C-130's, S-61's) with GOM.
This Embassy can see no policy objection from this end for a Korean sale of grenades.
According to a local representative of British Crown Agents, the U.S. Army has tendered on this same purchase.

claims.claim_text: British Crown Agents formerly handled many Malaysian purchases of U.S. military equipment and armaments.
Last month, responsibility for military procurement was given to GOM State Trading Company Pernas Wakil Berhad.

claims.claim_text: GOM State Trading Company Pernas Wakil Berhad called for new bids.

The go-betweens made inquiries so that they could tender.

The price up-date was requested so that Crown Agents could resubmit the U.S. Army offer.
